===Pronunciation===
{{ja-pron|yomi=o|しょうぐん|acc=0|acc_ref=DJR|a=Ja-Shogun.oga}}

===Etymology 1===
{{IPAchar|/syaugun/}} → {{IPAchar|/ɕaugun/}} → {{IPAchar|/ɕɔːgun/}} → {{IPAchar|/ɕoːgun/}}

From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=しょうぐん}} compound {{m|zh|将軍|tr=tsjang<sup>H</sup> kjun|lit=leader + army}}.  Compare modern {{etyl|nan|-}} ''chiong-kun'', {{etyl|min|-}} ''ciŏng-gŭng''.

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|しょうぐん|kyu=將軍|hhira=しやうぐん}}

# commander of troops
# {{lb|ja|military|sort=しょうぐん}} [[general]]

=====Synonyms=====
* {{sense|military general}} {{ja-r|将官|しょうかん}}

=====Derived terms=====
{{der-top}}
* {{ja-r|大将軍|たいしょうぐん}}
* {{ja-r|征夷大将軍|せい.い たいしょうぐん}}
{{der-bottom}}

=====Usage notes=====
In modern military system, {{lang|ja|将軍}} refers to any military officers who have the ranks with the character {{m|ja|将}}, i.e. {{m|ja|大将|tr=taishō}}, {{m|ja|中将|tr=chūjō}}, {{m|ja|少将|tr=shōshō}}, and {{m|ja|准将|tr=junshō}}.

===Etymology 2===
From an abbreviation of {{m|ja|征夷大将軍|tr=seii taishōgun}}, meaning “the general who overcomes the barbarians”.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|しょうぐん|kyu=將軍|hhira=しやうぐん}}

# the [[supreme]] [[generalissimo]] of [[feudal]] [[Japan]]: the [[shogun]]
